q: What are some common causes of back pain?
a: Back pain can have many causes, including injuries like pulled muscles or strains, medical conditions like slipped discs or sciatica, and rarely, serious problems like broken bones, cancer, or infections.

q: How can I ease back pain myself?
a: To ease back pain, you can stay active, take anti-inflammatory medicine like ibuprofen, use ice or heat packs, and try exercises and stretches specifically for back pain. Avoid staying in bed for long periods of time.

q: What exercises and stretches can help with back pain?
a: There are specific exercises and stretches you can do to help with back pain, such as those shown in NHS back pain pilates video workout or exercises recommended by Chartered Society of Physiotherapy or BackCare. Walking, swimming, yoga, and pilates may also help.

q: When should I see a GP for back pain?
a: You should see a GP for back pain if it doesn't improve after treating it at home for a few weeks, if it's stopping you from doing your daily activities, if the pain is severe or getting worse over time, or if you're worried about the pain or struggling to cope.

q: What should I do if I have severe back pain?
a: If you have severe back pain that is always there and so bad it's hard to think or talk, or if you cannot sleep or find it very hard to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash, or dress, you should seek urgent medical attention.

q: What should I do if I have back pain with certain symptoms?
a: If you have back pain with symptoms like pain, tingling, weakness, or numbness in both legs, numbness or tingling around your genitals or buttocks, difficulty peeing, loss of bladder or bowel control, or chest pain, you should call 999 or go to A&E.

q: What treatments are available for back pain?
a: Treatments for back pain can include painkillers, muscle relaxants, group exercise sessions, physiotherapy, manual therapy, cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), nerve-sealing procedures, and in some cases, surgery.

q: When might surgery be recommended for back pain?
a: Surgery may be an option for back pain caused by a medical condition like a slipped disc if other treatments have not helped. It's best to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice.

q: What is cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) for back pain?
a: Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is a type of therapy that can help individuals cope with the pain and emotional effects of back pain. It focuses on changing thoughts, behaviors, and emotions related to pain.

q: What are some self-help tips for managing back pain?
a: Some self-help tips for managing back pain include maintaining good posture, using ergonomic furniture and equipment, practicing stress management techniques, incorporating regular physical activity and exercise, and avoiding activities that may strain the back.

q: What are some causes of back pain?
a: Many factors can cause back pain, including injury, medical conditions like a slipped disc or sciatica, and rarely, more serious issues like broken bones, cancer, or infection.

q: What can I do to ease back pain myself?
a: You can try staying active, using anti-inflammatory medicine like ibuprofen, using heat and cold packs, and doing exercises and stretches for back pain. It is important not to stay in bed for long periods of time.

q: Can you recommend some exercises and stretches for back pain?
a: There are specific exercises and stretches that can help with back pain. However, if your pain worsens, it is best to stop and seek advice from a GP. You can find back pain exercises on the NHS website, as well as from organizations like the Chartered Society of Physiotherapy and BackCare.

q: When should I see a GP for back pain?
a: You should see a GP if your back pain does not improve after treating it at home for a few weeks, if it is stopping you from doing your day-to-day activities, if the pain is severe or getting worse, or if you are worried about the pain or struggling to cope.

q: What does severe back pain mean?
a: Severe back pain refers to pain that is always there and so intense that it's hard to think or talk. It may cause sleep disturbances and make it very difficult to move, get out of bed, go to the bathroom, wash, or dress.

q: When should I seek urgent advice for back pain?
a: You should seek urgent advice from a GP or call 111 if you have back pain accompanied by a high temperature, unexplained weight loss, a lump or swelling in your back, pain that does not improve after resting or worsens at night, pain that is aggravated by sneezing, coughing, or bowel movements, or if the pain originates from the top of your back (between your shoulders).

q: What should I do if I have certain symptoms with back pain?
a: If you experience back pain along with symptoms such as pain, tingling, weakness or numbness in both legs, numbness or tingling around your genitals or buttocks, difficulty urinating, loss of bladder or bowel control, or chest pain, it is recommended to call 999 or go to A&E immediately.

q: What are some treatments for back pain?
a: Treatments for back pain may include painkillers, muscle relaxants, group exercise sessions, physiotherapy, manual therapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, and, in some cases, procedures to block pain signals or surgery.

q: Can a GP prescribe painkillers for back pain?
a: Yes, if your back pain is severe or not improving, a GP may prescribe painkillers or muscle relaxants to help manage the pain.

q: Is surgery an option for back pain?
a: Surgery may be an option for back pain caused by a medical condition such as a slipped disc if other treatments have not been successful in relieving the pain.
